qas.question: What wasn't racial identity governed by in Brazil?
What were Brazillian children never automatically identified with the type of?
What may full siblings belong to?

context: Basically, race in <a0_0>Brazil<a0_0/> was "biologized", but in a way that recognized the difference between <a4_0>ancestry<a4_0/> (which determines genotype) and phenotypic differences. There, racial identity was not governed by <a1_0>rigid descent rule<a1_0/>, such as the one-drop rule, as it was in the United States. A Brazilian child was never automatically identified with the <a2_0>racial<a2_0/> type of one or both parents, nor were there only a very limited number of categories to choose from, to the extent that full siblings can pertain to <a3_0>different racial groups<a3_0/>.
